title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.23 | 16-02-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session, we will be discussing from the 23rd verse of the 8th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, continuing the prayers by Queen Kunti.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the topic: Queen Kunti's prayers from the Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: O Hrishikesha, master of the senses and lord of lords, you have released your mother Devaki who was long imprisoned and distressed by the envious king Kamsa and me and my children from a series of constant dangers.
segments.summary: The speaker recites and translates the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam, highlighting Kunti's prayer to Krishna, acknowledging his protection of Devaki and herself.

segments.key_quote: Krishna could not be killed as soon as he was born by Kamsa.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the story of Devaki's imprisonment by Kamsa, the prophecy of Krishna's birth, and Vasudeva's efforts to protect Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Krishna bestows more favor upon a devotee who is in greater dangers.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses Kunti's situation as a widow with young children in Dhritarashtra's palace, the dangers faced by the Pandavas, and how Krishna's grace is especially potent for devotees in helpless situations.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is always there to protect us and Krishna wants us to depend on him for all protection so that we become attached to him.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that material existence causes us to forget Krishna and rely on our own arrangements, while true protection comes from developing attachment to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Krishna agrees to become the son only of the most advanced devotee.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Devaki was not an ordinary woman, as only an advanced devotee can become Krishna's mother, and reinforces Krishna's supreme position, stating that everyone is subordinate to Him.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is a supreme controller above everyone else.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the roles of demigods like Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu in managing the material world and the three gunas, while emphasizing that Krishna is the supreme controller above all.

segments.key_quote: I must utilize my senses for Krishna's service.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of 'Hrishikesha' as the master of the senses and emphasizes the importance of using our senses in Krishna's service to achieve liberation and return to Godhead.
